entry.summary: The discussion between the two individuals is about Bitcoin and its availability on different Linux distributions. It is observed that if you are an Ubuntu user, then you will be stuck with version 0.6.2, which has not been updated since 2012. Similarly, for those still using Debian Squeeze, the version available is 0.3.24, which does not include any issues fixed since then. Moreover, nearly every distro links bitcoin against libdb5.1, which means wallets run once with those packages will never be usable again in an "official" Bitcoin build. The user further mentions that package maintainers are doing mostly a good job of providing the mainline Bitcoin client to users.The conversation later shifts towards the possibility of hacking a pool to mine Bitcoins or segmenting the network to have some miners do the work. However, it is observed that this is not a long-lived option, and the proposed attacks would yield similar costs as foregone income from alternative attacks. The theoretical limit on difficulty is discussed, and it is noted that every 2016 blocks can at most lower the difficulty by a factor of 4. Furthermore, the signatures for the Bitcoin release cannot be inside the tarball because they sign the tarball. It is also mentioned that SSL is mostly a false sense of security due to many CAâ€™s who will provide anyone a certificate with your name on it. In conclusion, the conversation is centered around Bitcoin and its availability on different Linux distributions and various security issues related to it.
